BRCPS Travels Around the World! (virtually)

Over the last couple weeks, BRCPS Upper School staff and students have been coming together for a “virtual travel” program. Using technology to support instruction, teachers lead students in trips across the globe with photos and facts. The program encourages students to use their imagination to envision a world without borders by virtually seeing and experiencing the beautiful people and cultures in various countries.

The weekly adventures culminate in students answering questions about what they have learned, with a weekly winner who gets a $15 Amazon gift card!

Keep an eye out for information to join the next Boston Renaissance virtual trip around the world!

BRCPS works hard to ensure the positive social and emotional development of our students. As part of our 2nd Grade social emotional learning this year, we kicked off 2020 with a fun screening of the movie Inside Out, with an emphasis on learning to regulate and understand our emotions.

This morning all 2nd Grade classrooms watched the movie and spent time engaging in activities around the topic of understanding and sharing their emotions - and we will be using the movie and characters as a means to support social-emotional development and self-regulation as the school year progresses.

Teachers are excited about this fun, creative way to nurture students’ social-emotional development, partnering with our school counseling team. And in true BRCPS spirit, the counseling team got involved in a big way, visiting every 2nd grade classroom in costume! Enjoy these fun pics!

The 2nd annual BRCPS Lower School Character Day Parade capped off this year's month-long Lower School Reading Challenge!

See scholars dressed as their favorite storybook characters toward the end of the video!

From May 11 to April 12th BRCPS lower school scholars set classroom and individual reading goals, increased their read aloud times, charted their progress, voted on favorite books, practiced concentration and reading stamina in extra read-alouds, class reading and independent reading, all of which culminated in the Character Day parade at the end of the month. For the Storybook Character Day Parade scholars chose their favorite storybook character, brought a book with that character to school and dressed up as that character to take part in a parade through the entire school cheered on by classmates and parents!

#BRCPS Celebrates #NationalSTEMday!

Watch highlights from our recent Science Fair which capped off the school's participation in the first ever #MASTEMweek!

Check out more from our STEAM Week at https://www.bostonrenaissance.org/in-the-spotlight/

Boston Renaissance Charter Public School was proud to participate in the first ever Massachusetts STEM Week, a special statewide initiative to boost students’ interest and raise awareness of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics education.

At BRCPS, we included Arts and declared it our first annual STEAM Week! Students engaged in science-related activities and projects throughout the week, with hands-on learning projects, games, videos, competitions, and more. They were treated to visits from parents and community members with STEAM careers, and a few grades took field trips (or will soon) to the Museum of Science. BRCPS Scholars have shown great interest in these subjects and we plan to continue looking for ways to expand STEAM learning throughout the school year.

Boston Renaissance Honors Moms and the Women in our Scholars’ Lives!

This morning BRCPS hosted a special event honoring our scholars’ mothers, grandmothers, aunties, and other female role models, with over 250 guests in attendance! The program included a guided meditation, live performance by the Voices of Renaissance Chorus, and some delicious breakfast treats for all. It was so nice to see the women in our school community have time for dialogue and fellowship!

Our goal with this event - as with those hosting our Dads and male role models earlier this year - was to show our appreciation for the adults who raise, support, and love our scholars every day. We Thank You for all you do, and look forward to continuing to build strong connections between school and home. It is so powerful for our children to know they are loved and supported by this community of caring adults! Have a wonderful Memorial Day weekend!

Just in time for #EarthDay this year #BRCPS scholars got a special visit from expert Climate Change scientist Dr. Jackie Richter-Menge!

Dr. Menge explained to our scholars how as a leading scientist at the CRREL (Cold Regions Research Engineering Laboratory) in Hanover, NH., she has been studying the changing thickness of arctic polar ice for many years now to see how it reacts to changing temperatures in our atmosphere.

She talked about the technology she invented to measure the thickness of the ice year-round from anywhere in the world, the many wild arctic animals she has encountered, and all the tools, gear and especially all the very warm clothes it takes to work in such a challenging environment.

She's also the proud mom of our very own 1st grade teacher, Ms. Menge!

BRCPS Celebrates Hispanic Heritage Month!
Today the Library of Congress in collaboration with the Consortium of Latin American Studies Programs (CLASP) awarded The Américas Award, to the children's book "Ada's Violin" about the famous "Recycled Orchestra" from the city of Cateura in Paraguay. Here we see BRCPS scholars with "Recycled instruments" they made themselves after reading about the orchestra!

The Américas Award is given each year in recognition of U.S. works of fiction, poetry, folklore, or selected non-fiction published in the previous year in English or Spanish that authentically portray Latin America, the Caribbean, or Latinos on the United States.

Check out Ava's Violin at your local library today or online here: https://youtu.be/vzPyF3JYcfU

June 8, 2017 at 5:52 PM ·

A very enterprising BRCPS scholar raised $2,917 with the help of her fellow elementary school students for charity using an idea she created on her own!

Inspired by the "Dress Down" Fridays at her sister's school, Tamil successfully gathered almost 200 student signatures on a petition which she presented to her Principal, asking her to implement a similar policy at BRCPS where students are allowed to wear clothes other than their uniform on half day Fridays if they bring $1 for charity.

Here we see Tamil and her best friends who helped her with the project present a check to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital for the $2917 that they raised this year.
